text: [Music]
reverse engineering compliance these are not words we often see
together but over the last little while
i've come to think they make a lot more sense than we might think and so
i'm looking forward to sharing that with you hi i'm adam shostak and these days i'm best
known for my work in threat modeling i've written a book on the subject created a card game elevation of
privilege to help people threat model advise a company areas risk that builds threat modeling
software and earlier in my career i created the microsoft threat modeling tool
i'm also on the review board here at black hat and helped to create the cve
also this is not something i normally bring up when i talk about my background but for today it's important
in the late 1990s i did reverse engineering
work where i broke the secure id card in early multi-factor authentication token
and i reverse engineered it using gdb greeting assembler dumps
and so when i talk about this it is from a place where i've done very classical
reverse engineering work to find bones in real systems so
with that what i want to share with you today is some thoughts on what reverse engineering is
i want to talk about compliance systems and threat modeling reverse engineering the pci standard
itself and then close out with a question that may be near and dear to your heart why bother
so let's get going so starting out with reverse engineering
when people talk about reverse engineering often we think about tools like kidra which is awesome and amazing
and reverse engineering is more than just tools it's a way of thinking
what does this thing do why does it work the way that it works what can i learn about it
by engaging with it take opening it up taking it apart
figuring out what's really there and all of that leads to the question
how can i change this how can i change its behavior offensively by writing an exploit or by
making it do things that the author didn't expect how can i make it present different
information to the person that's using it or if i'm a defender how vulnerable is this
thing what can i learn about it by taking it apart and so reverse engineering as a way of
thinking is tremendously important and powerful
and often times when we think about reverse engineering we focus in only on the software tools that we use
and i think that's a mistake it's like treating reverse treating reverse engineering as if it's
just gidra is like treating pen testing as if it's just kali linux there's more there and
that more is important so
reverse engineering is powerful and the thought processes involved in reverse
engineering apply very broadly in our lives in the work that we do
and today i want to talk about how to apply that to compliant systems
okay well what out what is a compliance system it's some sort of rule book it's
a set of things that you are required to do you'll do this you'll do that
and these are usually imposed by either contract or regulation
where um in order to sell a medical device for
example you have to go through approval from the fda that's a regulatory
reason to do this and sometimes like with pci they're imposed by contract
each is a set of things a checklist if you will
that we say we have to do these things and we in security often respond poorly
to the idea of checklist security and we often ask why those things
so behind every powerful rule book there's a committee that has written it
and that committee has a set of things that they're worried about
and that is a threat model of sorts and they hide that threat model and that
frustrates me and whether or not you know it that probably frustrates you as well
so i'm i'm talking about implicit threat models and when we talk about threat
models we're usually talking about explicit ones grant modeling is a way of thinking
about a system asking the question what's your threat model
means what are you worried about and often the answer is very short and simple i'm
worried about insiders i'm worried about an attacker with root on the system
we can also say something like let's threat model this by which we mean go through a process of analysis
to understand what can go wrong with a system what we're going to do about it
threatened models versus threat modeling a threat model often refers to the
documentation that emerges from an activity like this often
documentation that's written by a consultant and threat modeling can refer to any or all
of the above there's no one single way to threat model any more than there's one single
way to develop software and so when i say there's an implicit threat
model i'm not saying there's a specific thing which that committee has developed which
they've all agreed upon i'm saying there's an implicit bit of threat modeling in everyone's mind
so when i talk about threat modeling i'm going to give you a very quick intro to how i usually talk about threat modeling
to enable me to compare and contrast this normal model which i would use to
what we have to do to reverse engineer compliance so i think about four questions what are we
working on what can go wrong what are we going to do about it did we do a good job these four
these four questions form the basis of almost all the work that i do
when i get confused i come back to these four questions and if you're simply asking these four
questions about a system that you're working on your threat modeling and we can get a lot more specific and precise
we can use data flow diagrams with specific rules about how they're constructed
as the way in which we answer what are we working on when we get to what can go wrong we can
just ask what could possibly go wrong but we can also use a system like stride
stride is commonly associated with threat modeling and it's a mnemonic it's a way to help us structure our
thoughts it stands for spoofing tampering repudiation information disclosure denial of service an
elevation of privilege and these six groups of threats prompt us to be systematic in how we
look at a system so that we know that we've actually thought through
what can go wrong doing something more than just asking what can go wrong we can say how can
someone spoof this how can someone tamper with it for something like our credit cards
obviously information disclosure is a big threat as is repudiation claiming that you're not responsible for
a charge a package that showed up on your porch or the package never showed up on your
porch and so this structure is something we often bring to threat modeling
but not always so having this structure
for how we go about threat modeling will be important as i shift gears and talk about reverse
engineering pci and so for some context by pci i mean the
payment card industry data security standard version 321 which is the current version out there now
these folks have a hard job the work of producing a standard that applies to
the vendors down at a local fare or
amazon or a massive electronic or physical retailer like target
and having those rules be consistent and applicable is hard work um
having them be clear is hard work i don't want to pick on the pci folks in doing this i'm choosing
to use pci because it's easily available and it's familiar
if i were to pick a self-driving car security standard most of you would be lost that have to
spend most of the excuse me most of the talk explaining the standard and so i'm using
pci not because of any particular characteristic of its technical content
what i'm saying is i believe very broadly applicable to compliance
standards and i'm picking one that is familiar with respect to the folks who are
working on it with respect for the folks who are working on it so what is the standard
the standard is these six things uh build and maintain secure network and
systems protect cardholder data manage vulnerabilities etc and these six
high level goals translate into 12 standards or
12 elements and actually i'm going to stay here for a second and then there's a lot of sub
elements and when we go beyond this pci is 139 pages
and let's be frank it's a frequent source of arguments the security team ends up in
arguments with the rest of the business over why are we doing this do i have to
do that we've got something else we've got other priorities why are we doing
this and then the whole business ends up in an argument with the qualified security
assessors the qsa's the folks who come in to say are you in compliance with the standard
and so it's my belief
that engaging in some reverse engineering work
actually helps reduce these conflicts and get us better security with less
work let's talk about how so this this is a randomly chosen page of pci i
flipped through the standard this is what fell open and so let's look at it um it's three columns first column is
the requirement so we have a requirement 115 which we'll talk about as an example
is description of groups roles and responsibilities for management of network components and 116 is you have
business rule justification and approval for firewall open ports
the middle column is some testing procedures um make sure that the standards include
these descriptions and then there's a guidance column which is a little bit of discussion
and so there's 130 uh well there's 100 odd pages of this to be fair and we need
to talk about the whys why why is important there's a famous little book called start from why
and why motivates people why motivates the business to move past the check mark
nobody wants their business to be insecure but we end up
with this list of things that can be frankly pretty tedious um and if
when we're done with it we end up having no energy to do other security work
understanding the why can enable innovation by engineers engineering at its heart is really about
making trade-offs between complex sets of requirements
and finding a place where we satisfy all of them ideally in an elegant and
inexpensive way that the work that we're doing meets those requirements in a way that
actually allows us to ship something to sell it to customers and make some money and so
engineers are focused on that innovation that balancing act of this will satisfy all of these things
and if we know what those things are to be satisfied then we may have more flexibility
in the way in which we attempt to satisfy them and in theory
why can inform our conversation with the people assessing our work we can say we
believe that this meets the goal of the standard for these reasons and
the third column that guidance column in pci can really help us get to that point
so let's do some reverse engineering why why why so i ex i started looking at
this and i started to go right to the threats right what threat does this line address
because the the compliance standard is a set of mitigations to those threats
and so i would look at a line like 115 there's description of groups roles
and responsibilities where's the problem what's this this isn't a characteristic of the firewall
what's going on here what is what is the reason that this thing works the way it
does and so i gonna be honest i was really frustrated
when i was doing this uh it didn't make a whole lot of sense
and we know that this is a this is a phase that we go through as we reverse engineer things
we're pulling something new apart and we're scratching our
heads and what what is why [Music]
and so i went back to the four question framework and i said these are my north stars
and what i realized eventually is that i was not really answering the question
what are we working on what i realized when i was doing that
that pci has two distinct system models it has a model of process it has a model
of technology it doesn't really seem to have much of a model of people
separate from the process that they're executing and that's an interesting sort of thing when
we talk about people's exhaustion with the process but 115 turns out to be all about the
process right we have a description of the groups roles and responsibilities that we're looking at
and so i'm going to skip over some of the boring bits going through each and every
line in pci takes a lot of time and in fact
the project for which i was doing this we determined that we actually had sufficient answers for that project
without finishing going through pci and so there are some places where my model is not complete
but what i did was i iterated between the controls and the threats and the system models and i'm going to show you
what i did and i also published this as a white paper to make the work available for
anyone who wants to pick it up and play with it and so pci's model of technology
starts over here starts over here um we've got a model uh
we've got a credit card and the credit card runs through a point of sale system that point of sale system
as near as i can tell on the model only ever runs through wireless connections
through a wireless firewall to a card data environment which includes processing and storage
that card data environment talks through a separate firewall to an acquiring bank
and an acquirer is a bit of jargon for
the bank which acquires the transactions from the merchant and ships them back to the bank the issuer who is issuing the
cards to consumers and so we've got a model
of how this works here we also have a model of the process
there and on the top half of the model there's change management on the bottom half of the model there's system
deployment so in this model there's a bunch of interrupt things happen and you have to
take action based on them to review and whatnot and there's timers regularly review your firewall rule set
there's a review there's approval and there's execution and all of this feeds into tracking
and their model of system deployment is we have some standards which influence your configuration which influence your
deployment all of this feeds into those pesky technical systems which realize
the way in which the system is actually deployed and so
their model of threats is actually quite interesting um they're very focused on what i think
of as a prevent detect respond model and the threats that they are focused on
are primarily information disclosure threats part of stride if we want to think about it
part of the cia triangle of confidentiality integrity availability
if we want to think about it that way and also a different c compliance they have compliance threats
and management threats that are thought about in the standard and these are interwoven in a way
that in my world is quite unusual and so picking that out and understanding it
was a little tricky but now that i understand it i understand the standard better
and so the threats in this model i break out into threats to the process
and threats to the technology and i'm not going to walk through this table line by line but
threats to element c1 those interrupts are that the firewall rule set goes out of date and so pci
requirement 1.17 applies to that there are some timers with for example
there's a threat that old data is not deleted or not deleted securely which is covered by pci 3.1 bullet 2.
so we can think about these threats to processes we can think about threats to the
technology so interestingly and i said i didn't go through the entire standard but there's
no threats to the credit card itself the thing in my wallet is
to the my understanding not treated in pci it's all about
line seven the storage is the authentication data stored is the
full track data stored and these are interesting threats and i was talking about them with a colleague who said
storage is not a threat information disclosure is a threat like yup that's that's the way i think
about it too but in the standard the simple act of
storage which enables later accidental disclosure or later disclosure to an
attacker the act of storage is the thing they want to prevent okay
and so some of these are threats
that some of these are things that we want to prevent their information disclosure
and so we can build out a model of what pci is looking at
and in building out this model the last five says four should say five the last
five slides are my reverse engineering analysis why do i have to do this
because the pci folks don't share them they may or may not have made this
explicit in their internal working activity
if it's explicit i would like them to share it if it's not explicit i would like them to make it explicit and then
share it because i had to do a lot of painful work to figure this out
and in having done this work i feel that my understanding of pci
is much deeper than it was when i went through those 139 pages
with pen in hand thinking about each and every one of them and so
that work helped me develop an understanding and i hope that the threat model the white paper
the last few slides help you understand pci in a way that helped you deal with
it
excuse me so this brings me to the question of why bother
so the first reason to reverse engineer anything is it's because it's fun
reverse engineering the act of investigation the act of analysis
the discovery the aha moment the oh look at that right there
that stuff's fun right we in the black hat community
enjoy this work it's something that gives us a challenge and in overcoming
that challenge in learning we take enjoyment from that
and so the first reason to do reverse engineering is the joy of understanding
something the second reason is the profit
if we have a better understanding of a system
you know that's that's a lot of the talks here at black hat and in fact when we're in the program
committee meetings we'll often say you know
the attacks on this thing are not all that interesting but boy
this this presentation is gonna unlock a lot of presentations over the next couple of years
because they've done a good job of reverse engineering this thing and they
lay out a set of paths that enable further
analysis you don't have to do this because you're going to get a black hat talk and
reverse engineering in and of itself may or may not be enough so i don't want to make any commitment there please don't
take this as just reverse engineering is going to get you on stage here but
the act of reverse engineering is at the heart of a lot of our talks because it shows gaps in the rules it
exposes places that defenders are ignoring and that might be a technical gap
where you can get a closed comment through that one parser
will look at and another one won't you can find that this thing parses these
headers in one way and this one doesn't and so we can smuggle a request through
we can smuggle this stack smashing or heap overflow through
here and so take advantage of it and these gaps in the rules these places that
defenders are ignoring happen up and down the stack they happen at the bits and bytes level
and they happen all the way up at the procedural and managerial levels
and so showing these gaps in the rules reverse engineering for fun and profit for the
fun being the increase in understanding the profit being how you take advantage of systems or how you defend systems
better are reasons to do this work i believe in the long run this can
reduce conflict with auditors might not do so in the short term but in the long run
it will i think it will help but hey you know reverse engineering's goal
is to increase our understanding is to enable us to do new things and often
that puts us in conflict with the auditors
so i want to encourage you to threat model your systems threat modeling acts as a
language between teams over and over again when i'm helping companies
develop their threat modeling programs develop their skills what comes out of it is a conversation
between development and operations and sre and the sock
where folks are better able to understand the security assumptions
goals and requirements of a system and asking these four simple questions
of what are we working on what can go wrong what are we going to do about it and did we do a good job
enables non-technical folks management project managers
i don't wanna yeah enables those less technical folks to participate in a conversation about
security and enables the business to as it were engage in a conversation about the
business goals and so these compliance requirements start to make more sense when they are
part of a threat model the requirement to encrypt data at rest
to not store these to not store this information these are ways of addressing the
question what can go wrong their answers to the question what are we going to do about it
and by putting them into that context we gain a lot of power
so to those creating standards to those
imposing compliance requirements it is time to show your threat models why should every organization be doing
this analysis we should be demanding that that information be available
it will improve the standards when their models don't represent your systems it's easier to see that
and the requirements the controls are going to get adjusted they're going to get invalidated
there's some complexity here there's some risks in doing this when we if we threat model my demand here
then the answer is what can go wrong if everyone shows their threat models there's going to be
a little more gaming of the standards i'm not particularly worried about that not because i don't worry about gaming
the standards but because i am super aware that the standards are already being gamed every day
and so i think that's a problem that we have to
deal with already and it doesn't get that much worse the cost of assessment is going to ship
we'll need to retrain auditors we'll need to redo things but i believe it will be worth it
in helping us start from the y in helping us understand what it is that we
